abstract: Sean Durkin, the director of "Martha Marcy May Marlene," discusses a scene from his film, which plays in the New York Film Festival this week.
snippet: Sean Durkin, the director of "Martha Marcy May Marlene," discusses a scene from his film, which plays in the New York Film Festival this week.
lead_paragraph: Cults, paranoia and a breakdown of trust are among the central topics explored in the psychological drama "Martha Marcy May Marlene," written and directed by Sean Durkin. The film, which plays this week at the New York Film Festival before opening in theaters on Oct. 21, follows one young woman (Elizabeth Olsen) after she has escaped from a cult and has gone to stay with her sister (Sarah Paulson) and her sister's husband. In this video, Mr. Durkin narrates a scene from the film that illustrates the haziness of Martha's psychological state after her escape.

headline.main: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Martha Marcy May Marlene'
